title: Reaching & Responding
description: Explore how you reach for each other and respond to bids for closeness

questions.text: I feel warmth coming back when I reach for my partner.

therapeutic.rationale: How your partner responds when you reach for them shapes how safe it feels to keep reaching. Warm responses encourage connection; cold or absent responses create withdrawal.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't feel responded to warmly, explore specific moments. The other partner may not realize how their responses feel.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual warm responsiveness creates a positive cycle of reaching and connecting.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner typically respond when you reach for closeness?

questions.text: I notice when my partner is reaching for closeness with me.

therapeutic.rationale: Noticing your partner's bids for connection is the first step to responding. Missing these signals—whether through distraction or different expectations—can leave partners feeling unseen.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner doesn't notice the other's reaching, explore how each person signals. Bids for connection can be subtle and easily missed.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual attunement to each other's reaching creates opportunity for connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How does your partner signal they want closeness? Are there signals you might miss?

questions.text: I feel comfortable initiating closeness with my partner.

therapeutic.rationale: Comfort initiating reflects feeling safe to want and ask. Discomfort may signal fear of rejection, unclear signals from partner, or patterns worth examining.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner is uncomfortable initiating, explore what would help. Is it about how past initiations were received? Fear of rejection?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared comfort initiating creates balance in who reaches for whom.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes it easy or hard for you to initiate closeness?

questions.text: My partner's way of reaching for me feels inviting, not pressuring.

therapeutic.rationale: The quality of how we reach matters. Reaching that feels inviting creates openness; reaching that feels pressuring creates resistance. Both partners need to understand how their approach lands.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: If one partner feels pressured rather than invited, this needs attention. The reaching partner can learn to adjust their approach.
therapeutic.whenSame: Mutual experience of inviting (not pressuring) approaches creates safety to connect.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What makes your partner's approach feel inviting versus pressuring?

questions.text: There's a good flow of reaching and responding between us.

therapeutic.rationale: Healthy intimacy has flow—reaching, responding, mutual pursuit. When the dance feels stuck or one-sided, exploring the pattern can help restore balance.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different perceptions of the flow suggest different experiences. One partner may be reaching more and feeling unmet; the other may not realize the imbalance.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared sense of good flow indicates a healthy pattern of connection.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: Does the reaching and responding feel balanced between you? What would improve the flow?
